Award.AwardTitle: Using Routines as an Instructional Tool for Developing Students' Conceptions of Proof

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developers and researchers at TERC, the Education Development Center, and Mount Holyoke College are participating in the development and systematic investigation of a teaching model to assist teachers in developing ideas about proof in grades 2-5. The teaching model provides both a tool for learning on the part of elementary teachers and a model of practice from which they can learn as they implement it.

The project is a teaching experiment in which the model is iteratively implemented and refined, first with teachers experienced in incorporating ideas about proof into their classroom instruction (Phase 1), then with teachers who are relatively inexperienced, both in their own understanding of proof and in their knowledge of how their students can learn about proof (Phase 2). Research questions focus on developing the components of the model, the learning of teachers as they implement the model, and the learning of students as they engage in the instruction that is guided by the model, with particular attention to students with varied histories of achievement in grade-level work on number and operations.

The expected outcome is a teaching model that can be tested on a larger scale as well as instruments for assessing student learning and teacher understanding of proof. The model includes printed material with descriptions of the routines and instructional sequences, guidelines for implementing each component, and a teaching framework as well as written and video case examples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project’s major goal was to develop a teaching model to help second through fifth grade teachers integrate mathematical argument into their mathematics instruction. Despite a focus in national standards and recommendations, mathematical argument does not have a central presence in the elementary curriculum.  Most elementary teachers have not had an opportunity to learn about mathematical argument and have no experience integrating it into instruction.

 

Through close collaboration with a group of teachers experienced in incorporating mathematical argument into their instruction, project staff developed a framework and a set of instructional routines that support teachers to systematically engage students in developing habits of noticing, articulating, representing, and justifying general claims in the context of core grade-level content about number and operations. After the model was developed in classrooms of the experienced teachers, it was implemented and refined in classrooms with teachers inexperienced with mathematical argument.

 

The project also aimed to deepen understanding about how young students develop knowledge and practices that enable them to engage in mathematical argument and what it is that teachers need to know and be able to do in order to support this student learning.

 

Intellectual merit

 

We developed a teaching model, which consists of five phases: 1) noticing a pattern or regularity; 2) articulating a claim about that regularity; 3) investigating what has been noticed and articulated through representation; 4) constructing a mathematical argument about why the regularity occurs; and 5) comparing what occurs in one operation with what occurs in similar circumstances with another operation. With our collaborating teachers, this model was elaborated and implemented, resulting in the development of the educational resources described below.

 

The project created a video database of both classroom lessons and student interviews. The classroom lessons illustrate how elementary students learn to engage in mathematical argument and how teachers support that learning. Analysis of the student interviews led to the development of two theoretical frameworks that characterize what elementary students can do, given the opportunity to engage in the practice of mathematical argument.  The first framework characterizes students’ articulations of conjectures. The second characterizes students’ representation-based arguments. These frameworks provide both a practical foundation for classroom work and a theoretical foundation for further research. 

 

Broader impact

 

Based on the teaching model and on what we learned about students’ development of mathematical argument, we created a resource for teachers and teacher educators. The first component of the resource is a book, But Why Does It Work? Mathematical Argument in the Elementary Classroom (Heinemann, 2017).  The book focuses on how and why mathematical argument is central to mathematics in the elementary grades, how students develop this practice, how their work parallels the process by which professional mathematicians create mathematical ideas, and how the teacher supports student learning.

 

The second component consists of eight Lesson Sequences on Mathematical Argument, based on the teaching model and on what we learned about student understanding. Each sequence is implemented as a series of short sessions over the course of a semester in the way that many teachers use Classroom Routines or Number Talks. The third component is a selection of classroom videos that illustrate how students engage in mathematical argument and how teachers support their learning.

 

Teachers can use these materials to learn about what mathematical argument is, what it looks like in elementary classrooms, and how to facilitate it. In particular, the eight Lesson Sequences, provide a clear and coherent way to get started with mathematical argument.

 

Our student learning results indicate the positive impact on students who participated in the instructional sequences. Participating students scored significantly higher on assessment items that emphasized explanation and argument, interpreting expressions and equations, and understanding the structure of the operations than those in non-participating classrooms. Students from the collaborating classrooms drew on their knowledge of mathematical relationships, structures, and properties to solve the assessment problems and could justify their reasoning.

 

Key to the broader impact is the project’s focus on including all students in significant mathematical investigation. The collaborating classrooms were in public schools in urban centers, as well as suburban and rural towns, and a university-based private school. Some of the classrooms had significant numbers of special needs students, ESL students, and/or students from low-income families.  They included students who have a history of excelling in math and on state assessments and students who have had difficulty with grade-level mathematics and performed poorly on state assessments. The classroom videos illustrate how, through implementing the teaching model, teachers supported all students to work collaboratively as a community of mathematicians. With a range of entry points built into the instructional sequences, this range of students built mathematical arguments together, enabling all to progress in their mathematical thinking.
